730860f-c.title: Bridges - Kosciusko Bridge - Newtown Creek - Brooklyn.
730860f-c.text:
Kosciusco Bridge, over Newtown Creek: The new vehicular bridge which replaced the old Penny Bridge.

For additional data see "The New York Times, September 23, 1940.

P. L. Sperr

August 22, 1939
Views 1-3

730859f-c.title: Bridges - Kosciusko Bridge.
730859f-c.text:
Kosciuszko Bridge: A view across the area in Brooklyn where the new Kosciuszko Bridge will be thrown across Newtown Creek, linking Meeker Avenue in Brooklyn and Laurel Hill Boulevard in
Queens.
View 2 shows the $6,000,000 high-level span when completed, seen from Brooklyn. The bridge was formally named for the Polish patriot Thaddeus Kosciuszko by Mayor LaGuardia on September 22, 1940. For additional data see 'The New York Times," September 23,
1940.
View 1: August 13, 1938
View 2: August 22, 1939
P. L. Sperr
3) A more distant view of the bridge, seen from the Greenpoint
Avenue Bridge over New-town Creek.
P.L.Sperr  July 25, 1939

730933f-a.title: Bridges - Penny Bridge - Newtown Creek - Queens.
730933f-a.text:
Penny Bridge, showing the Bridge house at the foot of Laurel Hill Blvd.
View 1: August 13, 1938.
View 2: August 22, 1939.
P.L. Sperr

Note: The bridge was closed down when the new span, the Kosciusco Bridge, was built. The closing took place in 1939. These views are across Newtown Creek, from the Brooklyn shore.

730931f-b.title: Bridges - Penny Bridge [Meeker Avenue Bridge] - Newtown Creek.
730931f-b.text:
Penny Bridge (Meeker Avenue Bridge) connecting Queens and Kings counties at Meeker Avenue.
View 1: August 13, 1938.
Views 2,3: August 22, 1939.
P.L. Sperr

Views 2,3 show the bridge after it was closed down to all vehicular traffic when the new Kosciusco Bridge was constructed to replace it. The new bridge can be seen in these views.
